Lawrence Convention Center at Handmade Arcade! The holidays shine brighter than ever at the 11th anniversary of Kennywood‚Äôs Holiday Lights. Come make it part of your tradition select nights starting Nov. 15! This event is free, but gifts and foods will be available for purchase. Make sure to hop on the event trolley as it makes stops throughout Lawrenceville and Penn Avenue. Tickets include admission to their Winter Flower Show and Light Garden. The Wickhams: Christmas at Pemberley Nov. 30-Dec. 22, 2024 City Theatre Mainstage celebrates the beloved characters of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice in a companion piece to last season‚Äôs Miss Bennet: Christmas at Pemberley. As the events of Miss Bennett unfold upstairs, the house staff below have their own holiday scandals as they gather for Christmas at Pemberley. Who's Holiday! Nov.27-Dec. 22, 2024 (select dates) Leave the kids at home for this one. This R-rated show by Greer Cabaret Theater joins Cindy-Lou Who, now a grown-up, for a night of cocktails, cursing and fun. Handel's Messiah Dec. 7, 2024 Experience the majesty of Handel‚Äôs Messiah with conductor Manfred Honeck, the Mendelssohn Choir of Pittsburgh and your Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra. A Christmas Story: The Play Dec. 4-Dec. 22, 2024 (select dates) Experience the play version of Ralphie Parker's misadventures through all the trials and tribulations of a family holiday in A Christmas Story. Just don't try licking any lamp posts before or after the show. The Nutcracker with the Pittsburgh Ballet Theatre Dec. 6-27, 2024 (select dates) Snow settles across the city as a wonderful adventure begins in PBT‚Äôs The Nutcracker. Join Marie, her Nutcracker prince and the Sugar Plum Fairy on a journey into the Land of Enchantment. Five fanciful scenes, more than 150 unique costumes and Tchaikovsky‚Äôs enduring score make The Nutcracker a can‚Äôt-miss holiday tradition. Holiday Brass Spectacular Dec. 17, 2024 Join the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra for this annual one-night-only tradition! Usher in the holiday season with music from Baroque favorites to new arrangements of beloved holiday classics. Pittsburgh Creche Endowment Fund Established: 10/31/2006 Donate Now How the Cr√®che came to Pittsburgh is an example of how a diverse community joined together to accomplish a goal. In 1996, the Christian Leaders Fellowship displayed a Nativity scene near Gateway Center on city property. In 1998, the City of Pittsburgh decided such displays could no longer be erected on government property. Around this same time, Louis D. Astorino, a pre-eminent architect and member of the Christmas Festival Committee had visited the larger-than-life-sized Cr√®che at St. Peter‚Äôs Square in Rome‚Äôs Vatican City in 1993 and wanted to do something special for Pittsburgh‚Äôs Christmas Festival for the millennium. In 1997, the Festival Committee and the Christian Leaders Fellowship approved Astorino‚Äôs proposal to duplicate the Cr√®che in St. Peter‚Äôs Square at a new downtown Pittsburgh location where even more people could linger to appreciate it. Then, Catholic Diocesan Bishop Donald Wuerl contacted USX Chairman Thomas Usher, who arranged for the Cr√®che to be displayed on private property on the plaza outside of what is now the U.S. Steel Tower. Workers at the Civic Light Opera‚Äôs Construction Center built the stable and, in Rome, Umberto Mezzana who designed the original stable worked with Petro Simonelli who crafted the first nativity scene figures. Local foundations, businesses and unions contributed money, services and labor to the construction and assembly of the Cr√®che. The Sisters of the Holy Spirit now sew and maintain the clothes for all the life-sized figures. The new Cr√®che was dedicated on Dec. 6, 1999, and was displayed through Jan. 7, 2000. Every year since, volunteers and unions have donated their time and corporations have given services to help keep the Cr√®che a unique part of Pittsburgh‚Äôs holiday celebration. While much of the work on the Nativity is donated, not all the labor is free and other expenditures are necessary including truck rentals and police service. Because of winter weather conditions the nativity scene also suffers damage to the roof or to the plywood infrastructure and most years needs some repairs. It is for these additional labor and equipment costs and the as-needed restoration expenses that an endowment fund was created at The Pittsburgh Foundation. Despite all of the donated services, approximately $70,000 is needed annually to maintain the Cr√®che and to house it when it is not on display. When a shortage of funds presented the possibility that the Cr√®che might be discontinued, Christians of all denominations not only responded to address the need, but worked with The Pittsburgh Foundation to create this fund to endow The Pittsburgh Cr√®che so that it could be appreciated and enjoyed by future generations of Pittsburghers. The annual dedication of The Pittsburgh‚Äôs Cr√®che opens on Pittsburgh‚Äôs annual Light Up Night in November and remains open through Epiphany in early January. Each year an estimated 250,000 people stop to gaze at the life-like replicas and the manger scene that is the reason for the holiday celebration. The Cr√®che has become an attraction to downtown Pittsburgh allowing residents and out-of-towners to connect their beliefs with the joy of the season.

A Holiday Tradition for Over 30 Years! On Christmas Eve, Scrooge sits in his house with not a kind word for anyone; he just wants to be left alone until the "humbug" of Christmas is over. But four ghostly visitors - his former business partner, followed by the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Christmas Present, and Christmas Yet to Come - show him the error of his ways, and by the time Christmas Day dawns, Scrooge is a changed person. Adapted for the Stage by: Ken & Jane GargaroBased on the book by Charles Dickens YOUNG ARTIST PRODUCTION What is a Young Artist Production? The foundation of PMT‚Äôs mission is built on arts education, development, mentorship, and providing performance opportunities for young artists. PBT‚Äôs annual sensory-friendly performance of The Nutcracker returns! At this performance we welcome anyone with autism spectrum disorder, sensory sensitivity or other individual needs. These performances have a relaxed atmosphere which means they are perfect for families with small children. It‚Äôs a judgement free zone where performers, theater staff and patrons are accepting of additional sound and movement in the audience and lobby. At PBT we recognize that a theater performance can present a variety of barriers for many in our audience. We are striving to change that. Our sensory-friendly performances are a step toward making the excitement and beauty of a ballet performance barrier-free, accessible and welcoming to everyone in our Pittsburgh community. Our sensory-friendly performances are relaxed performances that are open to all. It is a judgment-free zone where theater staff and patrons accept (and expect) extra sound or movement in the audience and where we celebrate the myriad ways audience members can experience a live stage performance. Accommodations include lower sound levels, elimination of some special effects and house lighting at about 20%. We also offer quiet areas and activities in the lobby before and during the show and have additional staff on hand to help create a safe and welcoming theater experience. Plan Your Experience Tips to make your experience ‚Äúsensory-friendly‚Äù These performances feature a friendly, supportive environment for families with a loved one with special needs. Adaptations you can make at home are slight, including: Lower sound levels Adjust the brightness of the computer screen Take breaks during recorded videos and come back at any time Turn your camera off if you need a break during class Have fidget objects available or nearby It takes a village to produce a sensory-friendly production! PBT is deeply grateful for the support of our partners: Autism Connection of PA, the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust and our wonderful volunteers.
